docs.lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union announced a settlement yesterday in which the authority abandoned its demand for concessions on pensions and the union agreed to have all workers pay a portion of their health insurance premiums. Last night the executive board of the union, Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, voted 37 to 4 to approve the tentative 37-month contract. One member abstained. The city's 33,700 subway and bus workers are expected to vote on the agreement early next month; some are expected to oppose it out of unhappiness over having to pay toward health premiums for the first time.

headline.main: TRANSIT WORKERS IN DEAL TO SHARE HEALTH PLAN COST

docs.snippet: The M.T.A. gave up its pension demand in the 37-month deal and the union agreed for workers to pay toward health premiums.

byline.original: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and SEWELL CHAN

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: AS most Americans are aware, our auto industry is in a crisis. Workers' wages are falling, and hundreds of thousands of jobs are being sent offshore. America's largest parts supplier, Delphi, filed for bankruptcy protection, and General Motors, Delphi's main customer, may too, if a threatened United Auto Workers strike occurs next month. Meanwhile, Ford and its main parts supplier, Visteon, seem to be skidding down the same road.
docs.snippet: Opposition to a national health care plan is as much a part of the American trade union tradition as the picket line.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's no mystery why the old-time hacks used to call their yellow cabs a heart attack on wheels. Try sitting for 12 hours at a stretch while navigating a traffic-choked, potholed city populated by jaywalking pedestrians, traffic police and kamikaze drivers -- many of them fellow cabbies. Add a steady dose of stinging insults and haughty demands from backseat drivers. Top off the day with a profusion of fried food and sugared coffee, and it makes sense that cabbies suffer from soaring rates of high blood pressure, diabetes, lower back pain and shredded nerves.

headline.main: From the Wheel to the Treadmill

docs.abstract: BQE Fitness Complex, Woodside, Queens, has become late-night hang-out for taxi drivers wanting to get in shape and socialize with other drivers; Bhairavi Desai, New York Taxi Workers Alliance executive director, describes health hazards associated with job that keeps workers in stressful and sedentary state for 12-hour shifts; drivers discuss benefits of taking time to go to gym; photos (M)
docs.snippet: When fares grow more scarce after midnight, some cabbies head to a 24-hour health club in Queens.

multimedia.credit: Cabbies pull over in the middle of the night to work out at a 24-hour health club in Queens.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Saying Chinese Traders Aid Iran, U.S. Sanctions Them The Bush administration announced sanctions against Chinese companies that it accused of aiding Iran's weapons programs, insisting that Beijing cut off the trade at a time when President Bush is pushing China to condemn Iran's nuclear program. A8 Courts Protect State in China Courts in China often refuse to issue verdicts in cases against the government, making a 1989 statute that entitles people to sue the state a beguiling fiction, scholars say. A1 Iraq Discusses New Government Iraqi political leaders began negotiations to form a government that they hope will be supported by most of those elected to Parliament. A8 Outspoken Putin Adviser Quits The most outspoken of President Vladimir V. Putin's senior advisers abruptly resigned, warning that Russia's nascent political freedoms have been lost and the Kremlin's economic choices have been poor. A8 New Strife Feared in Sri Lanka Recent violence in Sri Lanka between the government and ethnic separatists, has raised fears of a resumption of a two-decade civil war. A11 Threat of Buffer Zone in Gaza Israel's military fired artillery rounds into the Gaza Strip and renewed its threat to form a buffer zone in northern Gaza, where Palestinian militants have been launching rockets aimed at Israel. A11 Scandal in Mexico's Drug Police Disclosures about corrupt federal agents have rocked the attorney general's office in Mexico and undermined President Vicente Fox's creation of an elite federal force to fight kidnappers and drug dealers. A3 NATIONAL A12-16 Wiretaps to Be Questioned In Terror Case Challenges Defense lawyers in some of the most prominent terrorism cases say they plan to bring legal challenges to determine whether the National Security Agency may have used illegal wiretaps against several dozen Muslim men tied to Al Qaeda. A1 A Shortage of Police Recruits Among the depleted ranks of police departments throughout the country, the King County sheriff's office in Seattle has started a program in which any deputy who can bring in someone who eventually becomes a sworn officer will get a bonus of 40 hours of extra vacation time. A1 A Maze of Property Courts Lillian Glasser, by all accounts, never intended to spend her twilight years in Texas. But to the consternation of Mrs. Glasser and the New Jersey authorities, Texas now has a major grip on her life and her $25 million fortune -- a consequence of a family feud and anomalies in probate practices from state to state. A12 Piles of Trash Tell Vivid Tales In New Orleans there is a new, grim ritual: residents having to don all manner of masks and other gear in order to go into their houses and get rid of every last thing covered in mold and mud. For some this is the only way to come to terms with what the hurricane has wrought. A12 SCIENCE/HEALTH Blood Thinners Pose Risk Patients being treated for heart attacks involving narrowed arteries and clots are often given overdoses of blood-thinning drugs in the emergency room, increasing their risk of bleeding, a study has found. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-12 Transit Union and M.T.A. Reach a Settlement The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the transit workers' union announced a settlement in which the authority abandoned its demand for concessions on pensions, but got the union to agree to have all workers pay a portion of their health insurance premiums. A1 Killer Nurse May Give Kidney A former nurse who pleaded guilty to killing 29 patients at hospitals in New Jersey and Pennsylvania has received permission to donate a kidney to an acquaintance in New York, as long as he first appears at his own sentencing. B2 Liberals Caution Clinton Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's support for the war in Iraq has outraged many liberal activists in the Democratic Party, who are warning of retribution. B3 EDUCATION B10 ARTS E1-10 DINING OUT E1-12 OBITUARIES B8-9 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-6 Former Star Pitcher Robs Store Jeff Reardon, who pitched for the Mets and Yankees and ranks sixth in career saves, was released on $5,000 bond, a day after he inexplicably robbed a Florida jewelry store. D6 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Enron Executive's Plea Deal Enron's former chief accounting officer, Richard Causey, has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to breaking federal law during his employment at the onetime energy giant, people briefed on the decision said. A1 F.D.A. Warns Guidant The Food and Drug Administration released a warning letter it sent to Guidant, restricting the ability of the troubled heart device maker to win approval for some new products. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: One year after the tsunami; Governor Romney bails out; trusting in charity's human touch; Lawrence Downes on mental disabilities and ''The Ringer.'' Column: Maureen Dowd. Crossword E9 Weather D7 TV Listings E11

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a geriatrician, I have provided care to several nursing home residents. I am surprised to this day that so many elderly are institutionalized out of convenience to their families. The answer to the long-term health care problem does not necessarily lie within the two big public programs, Medicare and Medicaid, nor in private insurance.

headline.main: Giving the Elderly Choices on Care

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Metropolitan Transportation Authority proposed making new workers chip in more to its pension fund than current workers do, it was enough to send the union out on strike and bring the nation's largest mass-transit system to a halt for three days. But the cost of pensions may look paltry next to that of another benefit soon to hit New York and most other states and cities: the health care promised to retired teachers, judges, firefighters, bus drivers and other former employees, which must be figured under a new accounting formula.

headline.main: HUGE RISE LOOMS FOR HEALTH CARE IN CITY'S BUDGET

docs.snippet: Under new accounting rules, New York City's annual expense for retiree health care is expected to at least quintuple and may top $5 billion.

byline.original: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH and MILT FREUDENHEIM; Michael Cooper contributed reporting for this article

docs.section_name: Front Page; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care seems to be heading back to the top of the political agenda, and not a moment too soon. Employer-based health insurance is unraveling, Medicaid is under severe pressure, and vast Medicare costs loom on the horizon. Something must be done. But to get health reform right, we'll have to overcome wrongheaded ideas as well as powerful special interests. For decades we've been lectured on the evils of big government and the glories of the private sector. Yet health reform is a job for the public sector, which already pays most of the bills directly or indirectly and sooner or later will have to make key decisions about medical treatment.
docs.snippet: To get health reform right, we'll have to overcome wrongheaded ideas as well as powerful special interests.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Long-Term Care Conundrum'' is no conundrum at all. It is clearly a question of the moral values, the sensitivity and the compassion of our society. The failure of our health care delivery system to provide for the elderly ill is a disgrace, and the only solution is universal, government-financed health insurance. But your editorial concedes defeat, saying long-term care coverage through Medicare is ''impossible to even consider'' because of the ''political climate.''

headline.main: Giving the Elderly Choices on Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Teri Marshall remembers the numbers: C1 and C2. Those are the vertebrae that her son lost in a grueling six-and-a-half-hour operation this summer to ease severe headaches and reduce pressure on his brain. Indeed, Ms. Marshall knows a lot about that operation, and about that condition, Arnold-Chiari Malformation, which also afflicts her and one of her daughters. One day, she knows, she may have to undergo the operation herself.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; With Neighbors' Aid, Ohio Family Rallies to Cope With Rare Medical Problem

docs.lead_paragraph: There is an eerie stillness here on Edgewood Avenue. Toys, broken glass and random pieces of furniture are strewn across yards. Not a single person is in sight. The only movement, nearly four months after the passing of Hurricane Katrina, comes from the stray cats that jump in and out of the ripped-open homes. Just west down the Gulf Coast, on Oak Street in Biloxi, the ground vibrates and the air is filled with the smell of diesel exhaust as laborers, on excavators, clean up after the storm, leaving behind empty lots, ripe for redevelopment.

headline.main: On Gulf Coast, Cleanup Differs Town to Town
